content.title: Iron Deficiency Anemia
content.summary: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is the most common cause of anemia worldwide, affecting ~2 billion people. It results from inadequate iron for hemoglobin synthesis, causing microcytic hypochromic anemia. Diagnosis requires identifying iron deficiency (low ferritin, low serum iron, high TIBC, low transferrin saturation) AND determining the underlying cause (blood loss, malabsorption, inadequate intake).
key_points: Most common anemia worldwide; most common cause of microcytic anemia
Classic labs: Low ferritin (most specific), low serum iron, high TIBC, low transferrin saturation
Always identify the CAUSE - GI blood loss in adults until proven otherwise
RBC morphology: microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic (low MCHC), anisocytosis (high RDW)
Treatment: Iron replacement (oral preferred) AND treat underlying cause
Response: Reticulocyte increase in 1-2 weeks; Hgb rise 1-2 g/dL in 4 weeks
content.statement: Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by inadequate iron for hemoglobin synthesis causing microcytic hypochromic anemia, diagnosed by low ferritin with iron studies confirming deficiency, and managed by identifying and treating the underlying cause while providing iron replacement therapy.

explanation.intuition: Iron is the central atom in hemoglobin that carries oxygen. Without iron, the body makes fewer and smaller red blood cells. Think of a factory running out of a key raw material - production slows and the product is smaller.
explanation.key_insight: Iron deficiency is a SYMPTOM, not a diagnosis. In men and postmenopausal women, assume GI blood loss (cancer, ulcer, angiodysplasia) until proven otherwise. A new diagnosis of IDA in these populations requires GI evaluation.
explanation.technical_details: Iron is absorbed in the duodenum; absorption enhanced by acid, vitamin C. Ferritin is the storage form; serum ferritin <30 ng/mL is diagnostic of iron deficiency. In inflammation, ferritin rises as acute phase reactant - use transferrin saturation <20% as alternative marker.

definitions_glossary.iron_deficiency_anemia: Anemia from inadequate iron for hemoglobin synthesis
definitions_glossary.ferritin: Iron storage protein; serum level reflects total body iron stores
definitions_glossary.transferrin: Iron transport protein; carries iron in blood
definitions_glossary.TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity; measure of transferrin's capacity to bind iron
definitions_glossary.transferrin_saturation: Serum iron / TIBC Ã— 100; reflects iron available for erythropoiesis
definitions_glossary.hypochromic: Pale RBCs from reduced hemoglobin content (low MCHC)
definitions_glossary.reticulocyte: Immature RBC; count rises with erythropoietic response to iron
definitions_glossary.anisocytosis: RBC size variation; reflected by elevated RDW
definitions_glossary.hepcidin: Hormone regulating iron absorption; elevated in inflammation, suppresses absorption
definitions_glossary.occult_GI_bleeding: GI blood loss not visible in stool; common cause of IDA in adults
definitions_glossary.malabsorption: Impaired iron absorption (celiac, gastric bypass, achlorhydria)

iron_metabolism.absorption: Duodenum and proximal jejunum; enhanced by acid, vitamin C
iron_metabolism.transport: Transferrin carries iron to bone marrow
iron_metabolism.storage: Ferritin in liver, spleen, bone marrow
iron_metabolism.regulation: Hepcidin controls absorption and release from stores

stages_of_iron_deficiency.stage_1: Depleted iron stores (low ferritin); normal hemoglobin
stages_of_iron_deficiency.stage_2: Iron-deficient erythropoiesis (low transferrin saturation); normal hemoglobin

blood_loss.menstrual: Most common cause in premenopausal women

causes.inadequate_intake: Primarily infants, children, pregnant women, strict vegans

laboratory_findings.peripheral_smear: Microcytic hypochromic RBCs; target cells; pencil cells

ferritin_interpretation.with_inflammation: Ferritin is acute phase reactant; use <100 ng/mL as cutoff; or rely on transferrin saturation <20%

differential_diagnosis: Anemia of chronic disease (ferritin normal/high, TIBC low)
Thalassemia trait (normal iron studies, target cells, MCV often <70)

identify_and_treat_cause.GI_evaluation: All men and postmenopausal women with unexplained IDA need upper and lower endoscopy
identify_and_treat_cause.celiac_testing: Consider if GI workup negative or refractory to treatment

agents: Ferrous sulfate 325 mg (65 mg elemental) TID
oral_iron.dose: 150-200 mg elemental iron/day in divided doses
oral_iron.duration: Continue 3-6 months after Hgb normalizes to replete stores
tips: Take on empty stomach for best absorption

IV_iron.considerations: Infusion reactions (premedicate with older formulations); anaphylaxis rare but possible

definition.@value: Anemia resulting from inadequate iron stores for hemoglobin synthesis, characterized by microcytic hypochromic red blood cells and low serum ferritin

scopeNote.@value: Most common anemia worldwide; always identify underlying cause

learning_objectives: Interpret iron studies to diagnose iron deficiency
Distinguish iron deficiency from other microcytic anemias
Identify appropriate workup for underlying cause
Recognize indications for IV iron therapy
clinical_pearls: Ferritin <30 ng/mL = iron deficiency; <15 ng/mL is definitive
In inflammation, ferritin rises - use transferrin saturation <20% instead
New IDA in men or postmenopausal women = GI workup (colonoscopy + EGD)
Reticulocyte count rises in 1-2 weeks - use to monitor response
Continue iron 3-6 months AFTER Hgb normalizes to replete stores
common_misconceptions: All microcytic anemia is iron deficiency - thalassemia has normal iron studies
Oral iron should be taken with meals - best absorbed on empty stomach
Stop iron when hemoglobin normalizes - need 3-6 more months to replete stores

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
UpToDate. Causes and diagnosis of iron deficiency and iron deficiency anemia in adults. 2024.
